items.title: pandas.testing.assert_series_equal precision defaults changed in pandas 1.1.0
items.body:
Pandas 1.1.0 changed the default precision tolerances in the `assert_series_equal` and similar functions: https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/30562.  This is causing test failures on the Azure checks that use the most recent pandas version, e.g.:  https://dev.azure.com/solararbiter/pvlib%20python/_build/results?buildId=3877&view=logs&j=ee50eb0a-7467-5494-0f35-e3b863355bb0&t=2efe8f58-8c60-5d45-8189-b00aa6aac1e4&l=209

I think maybe the best way to fix this is to wrap the pandas functions with our own with some version-checking logic.  Or we could rework all the failing tests to use more precise values, or bump the minimum pandas version to 1.1.0, neither of which seems like a good option to me.

items.title: Speedup of singlediode._lambertw function
items.body:
I have an application where I need to evaluate _lambertw many many times. Even a small speedup would be helpful. Currently _lambertw calculates IV curve points like `I_x`, `I_xx` that I don't need. What about adding an input flag that allows us to skip the evaluation of some parameters? 

The version I wrote to do this is below, but there are other ways this could be done as well.

```python
def _lambertw(photocurrent, saturation_current, resistance_series,
              resistance_shunt, nNsVth, ivcurve_pnts=None,
              calculate_all=False):
    if calculate_all:
        # Compute short circuit current
        i_sc = _lambertw_i_from_v(resistance_shunt, resistance_series, nNsVth,
                                  0.,
                                  saturation_current, photocurrent)

    # Compute open circuit voltage
    v_oc = _lambertw_v_from_i(resistance_shunt, resistance_series, nNsVth, 0.,
                              saturation_current, photocurrent)

    params = {'r_sh': resistance_shunt,
              'r_s': resistance_series,
              'nNsVth': nNsVth,
              'i_0': saturation_current,
              'i_l': photocurrent}

    # Find the voltage, v_mp, where the power is maximized.
    # Start the golden section search at v_oc * 1.14
    p_mp, v_mp = _golden_sect_DataFrame(params, 0., v_oc * 1.14,
                                        _pwr_optfcn)

    # Find Imp using Lambert W
    i_mp = _lambertw_i_from_v(resistance_shunt, resistance_series, nNsVth,
                              v_mp, saturation_current, photocurrent)

    if calculate_all:
        # Find Ix and Ixx using Lambert W
        i_x = _lambertw_i_from_v(resistance_shunt, resistance_series, nNsVth,
                                 0.5 * v_oc, saturation_current, photocurrent)

        i_xx = _lambertw_i_from_v(resistance_shunt, resistance_series, nNsVth,
                                  0.5 * (v_oc + v_mp), saturation_current,
                                  photocurrent)

    if calculate_all:
        out = (i_sc, v_oc, i_mp, v_mp, p_mp, i_x, i_xx)
    else:
        out = (v_oc, i_mp, v_mp, p_mp)

    # create ivcurve
    if ivcurve_pnts:
        ivcurve_v = (np.asarray(v_oc)[..., np.newaxis] *
                     np.linspace(0, 1, ivcurve_pnts))

        ivcurve_i = _lambertw_i_from_v(resistance_shunt, resistance_series,
                                       nNsVth, ivcurve_v.T, saturation_current,
                                       photocurrent).T

        out += (ivcurve_i, ivcurve_v)

    return out
```

items.title: Test failure: test_psm3::test_get_psm3_tmy
items.body:
The test data file we use for the NSRDB TMY API test is out of date.  In particular, it seems that the temperature, wind speed and direction, and albedo values have changed to some extent.  The various Test_conda_linux azure checks have been failing because of this. 

This dataset (tmy-2017) is intended to be static over time, but the version the API had been serving until recently was apparently a preliminary version that has now been replaced with the official version.  So hopefully this issue won't be recurring if we update our test file to match the API data, which is what I suggest doing.  Acceptable?

See https://github.com/NREL/developer.nrel.gov/issues/159 for further details.

items.title: Why remove parallelization for bifacial.py?
items.body:
Previous versions of pvlib had a run_parallel_calculations=True option in bifacial.pvfactors_timeseries(). Why was this removed in the current version?

Ideally I'd like to see parallel calculations restored.

The default could be to set run_parallel_calculations=False, which might help with avoiding runtime errors.

items.title: codecov/project/tests PR check always fails
items.body:
I don't really know what the `codecov/project/tests` check is trying to tell me.  Seems like it's always 0.00% out of the 95.00% target.  I see that the target is indeed 95% per: https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/master/.codecov.yml#L23

I'd like to get this test passing and see green checkmarks next to PRs again.  Aside from the 0.00% which I could forgive as a buggy github integration, what I really don't understand is why this check is failing when codecov reports 96.85% coverage for the tests folder: https://codecov.io/gh/pvlib/pvlib-python/tree/minigalleries/pvlib/tests

I can only assume that improving coverage would satisfy the test.  Seems like the coverage is getting dragged down by helper code (test data creation?) that isn't intended to get called in the test suite itself, like some functions here:
- https://codecov.io/gh/pvlib/pvlib-python/src/master/pvlib/tests/test_numerical_precision.py
- https://codecov.io/gh/pvlib/pvlib-python/src/master/pvlib/tests/iotools/test_ecmwf_macc.py

So if we wanted to get some quick coverage points back, we could add a `# pragma: no cover` comment ([docs](https://coverage.readthedocs.io/en/v4.5.x/excluding.html)) to those functions.  I'll open a PR shortly to see if this makes a difference.

In the past that 95% threshold has been lowered to accommodate changes in the test code, so that's another option.

items.title: Add Bill Marion's diffuse IAM integration method?
items.body:
Is there interest in an implementation of Bill Marion's "Numerical method for angle-of-incidence correction factors for diffuse radiation incident photovoltaic modules" https://doi.org/10.1016/j.solener.2017.03.027 ?  

Since the method itself just integrates an arbitrary AOI correction model over the relevant portion of the sky, I'm imagining a function like this that you could pass the other IAM functions into:

```python
def marion_integrate(function, surface_tilt, region, N=180):
    """
    Integrate an incidence angle modifier (IAM) function over solid angle
    to determine a diffuse irradiance correction factor using Marion's method.

    Parameters
    ----------
    function : callable func(aoi)
        The IAM function to evaluate across solid angle.  Must take only one
        parameter, the angle of incidence in degrees.

    surface_tilt : numeric
        Surface tilt angles in decimal degrees.
        The tilt angle is defined as degrees from horizontal
        (e.g. surface facing up = 0, surface facing horizon = 90)
        surface_tilt must be in the range [0, 180]

    region : {'sky', 'horizon', 'ground'}
        The region to integrate over.  See [1]_ for details.

    N : int, default 180
        The number of increments in the zenith integration.

    Returns
    -------
    iam : numeric
        The incident angle modifier for the specified region.

    References
    ----------
    .. [1] B. Marion "Numerical method for angle-of-incidence correction
       factors for diffuse radiation incident photovoltaic modules",
       Solar Energy, Volume 147, Pages 344-348. 2017.
       DOI: 10.1016/j.solener.2017.03.027
    """
```

items.title: Make building docs on windows slightly easier
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Running `make html` on a Windows system that doesn't have `make` installed fails.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Would be nice to be able to run `make html` without having to install make on Windows.  Newer versions of `sphinx-quickstart` create a `make.bat` file that invokes `sphinx-build`'s [make-mode](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/man/sphinx-build.html#cmdoption-sphinx-build-M).  Here's a copy of it in RdTools: https://github.com/NREL/rdtools/blob/development/docs/sphinx/make.bat.  I think just copying that file into `docs/sphinx` would make it work.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Can also just run `sphinx-build -M html source build` manually instead of using `make.bat` as a shortcut, it's a little more typing but not a huge deal.


Side note:  is it mentioned anywhere in the docs how to build the docs?  I'd expect to see it on the Contributing page, or maybe the Installation page, but I'm not finding it.

items.title: Use a development branch for API breaking changes towards v0.8.0 and beyond
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In discussing the next release in #955  two difficulties have arisen:
1. An uncertainty in how to describe releases via semantic versioning (bugfix release E.g. 0.7.3 vs minor release E.g. v0.8.0).
1. Releasing incremental, API breaking changes along with bugfixes/enhancements.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Utilize a development branch to centralize API breaking changes towards the goals of the v1.0.0.

Bugfixes and enhancements would still be merged straight into master as they currently are. Such changes are more straightforward and could be released to PyPI faster without concern of self-afflicted API changes and could enable a more bug-free and feature-filled PyPI version available for the masses.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Mark API breaking PRs as v0.8.0 and wait to merge them until they're all ready. 

This would not allow the community a chance to tryout these changes ahead of time and would be difficult for developers to ensure API consistency. 

**Additional context**
It looks like this was used in the past #178. Was there a reason for moving away from this workflow?

items.title: BUG:units for Uv & U1, convective thermal coefficient for Faiman and PVsyst, m/s should be in denominator
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
the units are unclear, m/s should be in the denominator, but looks like numerator

https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/e526b55365ab0f4c473b40b24ae8a82c7e42f892/pvlib/temperature.py#L216

and 

https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/e526b55365ab0f4c473b40b24ae8a82c7e42f892/pvlib/temperature.py#L306

**Expected behavior**
There probably isn't a standard, and we could argue, but IMHO the units should always be as explict as possible. I like the way [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_transfer_coefficient#Composition) makes them very explicit using parentheses
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1385621/77833007-5f84e780-70f7-11ea-936d-c76715feea48.png)

**Screenshots**
pvsyst:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1385621/77832932-c1911d00-70f6-11ea-8098-b1d04811cabf.png)
Faiman:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1385621/77832949-dff71880-70f6-11ea-8ecc-37025a988cd3.png)

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: e526b55365ab0f4c473b40b24ae8a82c7e42f892

**Additional context**
IMHO these units should uses parentheses like Wikipedia does for clarity:
* Uv & U1: [W/(m^2 K)/(m/s)] or [W/m^2/K/(m/s)] or [(W/m^2)/K/(m/s)]
* Uc & U0: [W/(m^2 K)] or [W/m^2/K] or [(W/m^2)/K]

items.title: BUG: netcdf4 conversion error in forecast.py
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The method `get_data()` from the parent class `ForecastModel` has a handling NETCDF data. It produces the following error on multiple tests within `test_forecast.py`:

`TypeError: <class 'cftime._cftime.DatetimeGregorian'> is not convertible to datetime`

**To Reproduce**
Run the command locally:

`pytest pvlib/tests/test_forecast.py --remote-data --pdb` 

This command will ensure the tests marked as `remote_data` are run and you'll be dropped into a pdb debugger.

**Expected behavior**
The formatted data would be received without error.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: 0.7.1 master
 - ``pandas.__version__``: 1.0.3
 - python: 3.7.4

**Additional context**
I'm unsure about the underlying origin but the disconnect seems to come through `get_data()` -> `_netcdf2pandas()` -> `set_time()` where `num2date` supplies a DatetimeGregorian that Pandas can't process. 

It's notable that there is a suggestion on line 279 of forecast.py about the potential to move to xarray's implementation of NetCDF rather than using the `_netcdf2pandas()` method. This avenue likely has the potential to be easier than continuing a pvlib implementation.

items.title: DOC: some API reference pages have broken "see also" links
items.body:
The see-also links on many of the API reference pages don't work because the names aren't in a format sphinx understands.  The majority are because the "module.function" path is only partially specified (e.g. `iam.martin_ruiz`).  I think it only works if you use the bare function name if it's in the same module, or you can specify the full path (including the leading `pvlib.`).  However there are a few misspellings like `equation_of_time_Spencer71()` and out of date locations like `pvlib.tmy.readtmy3()`. 

```
                                        function                       see-also name
0                        pvlib.location.Location                   pvsystem.PVSystem
1   pvlib.solarposition.equation_of_time_pvcdrom        equation_of_time_Spencer71()
2                 pvlib.solarposition.hour_angle        equation_of_time_Spencer71()
3                            pvlib.clearsky.bird  pvlib.atmosphere.relativeairmass()
4                             pvlib.iam.physical                   iam.martin_ruiz()
5                             pvlib.iam.physical                        iam.ashrae()
6                             pvlib.iam.physical                        iam.interp()
7                             pvlib.iam.physical                          iam.sapm()
8                               pvlib.iam.ashrae                      iam.physical()
9                               pvlib.iam.ashrae                   iam.martin_ruiz()
10                              pvlib.iam.ashrae                        iam.interp()
11                         pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz           iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse()
12                         pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz                      iam.physical()
13                         pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz                        iam.ashrae()
14                         pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz                        iam.interp()
15                         pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz                          iam.sapm()
16                 pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse                   iam.martin_ruiz()
17                 pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse                      iam.physical()
18                 pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse                        iam.ashrae()
19                 pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse                        iam.interp()
20                 pvlib.iam.martin_ruiz_diffuse                          iam.sapm()
21                                pvlib.iam.sapm                      iam.physical()
22                                pvlib.iam.sapm                        iam.ashrae()
23                                pvlib.iam.sapm                   iam.martin_ruiz()
24                                pvlib.iam.sapm                        iam.interp()
25                              pvlib.iam.interp                      iam.physical()
26                              pvlib.iam.interp                        iam.ashrae()
27                              pvlib.iam.interp                   iam.martin_ruiz()
28                              pvlib.iam.interp                          iam.sapm()
29                           pvlib.pvsystem.sapm             temperature.sapm_cell()
30                           pvlib.pvsystem.sapm           temperature.sapm_module()
31                  pvlib.pvsystem.sapm_aoi_loss                      iam.physical()
32                  pvlib.pvsystem.sapm_aoi_loss                        iam.ashrae()
33                  pvlib.pvsystem.sapm_aoi_loss                   iam.martin_ruiz()
34                  pvlib.pvsystem.sapm_aoi_loss                        iam.interp()
35                      pvlib.pvsystem.systemdef                pvlib.tmy.readtmy3()
36                      pvlib.pvsystem.systemdef                pvlib.tmy.readtmy2()
37                       pvlib.location.Location                   pvsystem.PVSystem
```

That list was generated with this quick and dirty script that scans through a local docs build and finds the broken see-also links:

<details>
  <summary>Click to expand</summary>

```python
# run from the pvlib-python/docs/sphinx/build/html directory
import bs4
import pandas as pd

#%% get a list of all the functions documented in the API Reference page

listing_file = 'api.html'

with open(listing_file, 'r') as f:
    html = f.read()

soup = bs4.BeautifulSoup(html)

listing = soup.find(id='api-reference')
link_elements = listing.find_all('a', class_='reference internal')
link_urls = [a.attrs['href'].split("#")[0] for a in link_elements]

#%% For each function page, check its "see also" entries for a link

missing_links = []

for link_url in link_urls:
    print(link_url)
    with open(link_url, 'r') as f:
        html = f.read()

    soup = bs4.BeautifulSoup(html)
    seealso_divs = soup.find_all('div', class_='seealso')
    for div in seealso_divs:
        entries = div.find_all('code', class_='xref')
        for entry in entries:
            # if sphinx didn't recognize the name, it doesn't wrap the "code"
            # element in an <a href=...> tag, so the code's parent won't have
            # that attribute
            if 'href' not in entry.parent.attrs:
                info = {
                    'page': link_url,
                    'function': link_url.split("/")[1].rsplit(".",1)[0],
                    'see-also name': entry.text
                }
                missing_links.append(info)

#%%

df = pd.DataFrame(missing_links)
print(df[['function', 'see-also name']])
```
</details>

items.title: BUG: microseconds treated as seconds in unused function spa.julian_day_dt
items.body:
Microseconds aren't scaled before adding with other time components, meaning they get treated as seconds: [spa.julian_day_dt](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/master/pvlib/spa.py#L433) 

```python
In [53]: pvlib.spa.julian_day_dt(2020, 1, 1, 0, 0, second=1, microsecond=0)
Out[53]: 2458849.500011574

# should return same as above but doesn't
In [54]: pvlib.spa.julian_day_dt(2020, 1, 1, 0, 0, second=0, microsecond=1e6)
Out[54]: 2458861.074074074

# shows us and s treated the same
In [55]: pvlib.spa.julian_day_dt(2020, 1, 1, 0, 0, second=1e6, microsecond=0)
Out[55]: 2458861.074074074
```

Note -- I don't think this function actually gets called anywhere, so I don't think it is causing any issues with solar position calcs or anything.  I only noticed it because I was reading through spa.py's source code.

items.title: [ENH] cell temperature from backside of module temperature measurements
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
recently a question was posed, given backside module temperature, how to include them in the model chain? Looking at the temperature models available, there isn't one that takes module temperature as input and returns cell temperature. [SAPM has a formula for adjusting module temperature to obtain cell temperature](https://pvpmc.sandia.gov/modeling-steps/2-dc-module-iv/cell-temperature/sandia-cell-temperature-model/) based on irradiance and constant "delta-T" parameter that is characteristic of the module. However this formula is bundled into `pvlib.temperature.sapm_cell`as [Eq (2)](https://pvlib-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/generated/pvlib.temperature.sapm_cell.html#equation-sapm2 ) and the function doesn't take module temperature as input

**Describe the solution you'd like**
add an optional kwarg to `pvlib.temperature.sapm_cell` that allows it to bypass the module temperature calculation.

https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/ae98bf94413ac1495c8fe3ed4ce985a3f74c3805/pvlib/temperature.py#L117

##### option 1:
add `module_temperature` as kwarg
```python
def sapm_cell(poa_global, temp_air, wind_speed, a, b, deltaT,
              irrad_ref=1000, module_temperature=None):
    if module_temperature is None:
        module_temperature = sapm_module(poa_global, temp_air, wind_speed,
    else:
        warning.warn('air temp and wind speed parameters ignored, overridden by module temp')
        return module_temperature + (poa_global / irrad_ref) * deltaT
```

##### option 2:
add new `pvlib.temperature.sapm_module_to_cell` func
```python
def sapm_module_to_cell(module_temperature, poa_global, deltaT, irrad_ref=1000):
    return module_temperature + (poa_global / irrad_ref) * deltaT
```

_note_: if option 2, then `pvlib.temperature.sapm_cell` could be updated to call `pvlib.temperature.sapm_module_to_cell`

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
* We could explain to users that they can _back out_ the conditions to the use `pvlib.temperature.sapm_cell`
* we could encourage users to formulate the equation themselves from the literature
* we could implement a 3rd SAPM function to perform this task seperately, call it `pvlib.temperature.sapm_module_to_cell`?

**Additional context**
related to [this post on the Google group](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/pvlib-python/CBThHDydaxs/oYuaKwJmAQAJ)

items.title: Error on Klucher's transposition model equation
items.body:
I noticed on the documentation that the modulating term F' in the Klucher expression for the transposition factor is missing an exponent of 2 ( https://pvlib-python.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generated/pvlib.irradiance.klucher.html )

It should read F' = 1-(DHI/GHI)^2 instead of F' = 1-(DHI/GHI)

The error appears only on the docs, the code is correct.

Can someone corroborate that?

Thanks a lot!

items.title: iotools tests fail when unable to connect to remote API
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Failures of network dependent iotools tests due to failures of the API server receiving the request affect consistency and confidence in our CI test results. 

**To Reproduce**
* This is difficult to reproduce since API failures are sporadic.
* An example of our CI failure can be found [here](https://dev.azure.com/solararbiter/pvlib%20python/_build/results?buildId=2807&view=logs&j=06aebe0f-636a-5f93-19d5-0c37b58d55c8&t=0878738c-c430-5911-4cfd-99d3ab677436).

**Expected behavior**
There are two important functionalities that are desirable: 
1. Ideally, a failure due to API server failure would be repeated with the hope that communication can be established. 

1. In the event that communication cannot be established during the test, it should be conditionally skipped with a warning that the test wasn't properly run. 

**Additional context**

This was originally identified by @wholmgren in https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/pull/897#issuecomment-590352000_

**Proposed solution**
Implement `@pytest.mark.flaky()`for all remote API dependent tests to reattempt if API is temporarily unreachable. This is already done for tests in `test_psm3.py` decorated with `@pytest.mark.remote_data`. 

~~I'm going to look for a pytest functionality to enable a conditional skip of the test in the event the API server is completely unavailable during the test duration. If you have a suggestion on how to accomplish this please let me know.~~
`@pytest.mark.skipif()` should work well for this application but the trick will be the implementation for each network dependent API.

items.title: Sphinx emits lots of warnings when building docs
items.body:
Sphinx currently emits a few types of warnings when building the docs, none are really a big deal but it clutters the output and makes #909 less effective.  I'll open a PR shortly to address:

Docutils warning
----------------------
```
/usr/share/miniconda/envs/test_env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/util/nodes.py:94: FutureWarning: 
   The iterable returned by Node.traverse()
   will become an iterator instead of a list in Docutils > 0.16.
```

I'm not 100% sure what this one is, but I assume it is related to the newest version of docutils deprecating something and sphinx hasn't caught up yet.  [example](https://dev.azure.com/solararbiter/pvlib%20python/_build/results?buildId=2804&view=logs&j=7e620c85-24a8-5ffa-8b1f-642bc9b1fc36&t=2febcae8-7f6a-51bb-45aa-d6e72c9ea7e2&l=128)

I'll play around with pinning the docutils version and see if that fixes it. 

Improper RST in gallery example
------------------------------------------

The I-V curve example generates `WARNING: Title underline too short.` because the page title got updated without extending the underline (my bad).  Easy fix. [link](https://dev.azure.com/solararbiter/pvlib%20python/_build/results?buildId=2804&view=logs&j=7e620c85-24a8-5ffa-8b1f-642bc9b1fc36&t=2febcae8-7f6a-51bb-45aa-d6e72c9ea7e2&l=187) 

First-line references
-------------------------

The first lines of docstrings get orphaned when they are copied into the API Reference docs page and Sphinx emits a bunch of warnings about it: [example](https://dev.azure.com/solararbiter/pvlib%20python/_build/results?buildId=2804&view=logs&j=7e620c85-24a8-5ffa-8b1f-642bc9b1fc36&t=2febcae8-7f6a-51bb-45aa-d6e72c9ea7e2&l=154)

There were a few votes in #909 to remove references from first lines of docstrings to prevent these warnings.  If nobody objects, I'll move references into the second part of the docstring, for instance:

Current:
```
def nrel_earthsun_distance(time, how='numpy', delta_t=67.0, numthreads=4):
    """
    Calculates the distance from the earth to the sun using the
    NREL SPA algorithm described in [1]_.

    Parameters
    ----------
    time : pandas.DatetimeIndex
```

New:
```
def nrel_earthsun_distance(time, how='numpy', delta_t=67.0, numthreads=4):
    """
    Calculates the distance from the earth to the sun using the
    NREL SPA algorithm.

    The details of the NREL SPA algorithm are described in [1]_.

    Parameters
    ----------
    time : pandas.DatetimeIndex
```

This is related to #837 but that's a much bigger job and I'd rather not tackle it right now.

items.title: soiling_hsu doesn't work with read_tmy3 - index must be monotonic
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
calling `pvlib.losses.soiling_hsu(read_tmy3(<tmy file>, coerce_year=<year>), ...)` raises `ValueError: index must be monotonic` because the last hour of a TMY3 file has been coerced to the same year as the first index, instead of the first hour of the next year

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```python
from pvlib.losses import soiling_hsu
from pvlib.iotools import read_tmy3
from pvlib.tests.conftest import DATA_DIR

greensboro = read_tmy3(DATA_DIR / '723170TYA.CSV', coerce_year=1990)
greensboro_rain = greensboro[0].Lprecipdepth
soiling_hsu(greensboro_rain, cleaning_threshold=6, tilt=10, pm2_5=1e-5, pm10=1e-5)
```
raises `ValueError: index must be monotonic`
<details>

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

items.title: ModelChain with PVSystem No aoi
items.body:
I created a simple script to test the ModelChain:

```
# Access weather data
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import datetime
import numpy as np
# import pvlib forecast models
from pvlib.forecast import GFS, NAM, NDFD, HRRR, RAP
from pvlib import solarposition

# specify location (Napoli, IT)
latitude, longitude, tz = 40.863, 14.2767, 'Europe/Rome'

# specify time range: 2 giorni
start = pd.Timestamp(datetime.date.today(), tz=tz)
end = start + pd.Timedelta(days=1)

tilt=30

irrad_vars = ['ghi', 'dni', 'dhi']
# model a simple PV plan
from pvlib.pvsystem import PVSystem as pv, snlinverter, retrieve_sam
from pvlib.temperature import TEMPERATURE_MODEL_PARAMETERS
from pvlib.modelchain import ModelChain
from pvlib.tracking import SingleAxisTracker
 
# Import the GFS module
model = GFS()

# modules
sandia_modules = retrieve_sam('cecmod')
module = sandia_modules['A10Green_Technology_A10J_S72_175']

#inverters
inverters = retrieve_sam('sandiainverter')
inverter =inverters.ABB__MICRO_0_25_I_OUTD_US_240__240V_
# temperature model
temperature_model_parameters = TEMPERATURE_MODEL_PARAMETERS['sapm']['open_rack_glass_glass']
# PV System ca 3kW
system = pv(surface_tilt=tilt,module_parameters=module, inverter_parameters=inverter,temperature_model_parameters=temperature_model_parameters,modules_per_string=5, strings_per_inverter=2)
 
# ModelChain
# wheather data
data = model.get_processed_data(latitude, longitude, start, end)
resampled_data = data.resample('15min').interpolate()
mc = ModelChain(system, model.location)
mc.run_model(resampled_data)
mc.ac.fillna(0)
```

I get:

`ValueError: could not infer AOI model from system.module_parameters. Check that the system.module_parameters contain parameters for the physical, aoi, ashrae or martin_ruiz model; explicitly set the model with the aoi_model kwarg; or set aoi_model="no_loss".`

This happens only if I select pvlib.pvsystem as system. If I select SingleAxisTracker, no problem
Is it a bug?

items.title: Clean up @needs_pandas_0_22 and @needs_pandas_0_17 pytest decorators
items.body:
It's apparent that the @needs_pandas decorators used in test_psm3.py are irrelevant now and should be removed. I'll create a PR to remove them and make sure there's no errors in the CI. 

For reference, @mikofski made good observations about this issue [here](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/pull/873#discussion_r375571469).

items.title: Implement pytest-remotedata for test_psm3.py
items.body:
An issue has been raised in #878 that the test suite is too slow. This issue suggests taking a quantitative step proposed by @kanderso-nrel to implement `pytest-remotedata` to help remove tests to speed up the process.

`pytest-remotedata` enables the ability to mark tests that need to access remote data and only execute them if pytest is provided a --remote-data flag. I plan to submit a PR implementing this for test_psm3.py. 

I'm also proposing that the --remote-data flag is implemented in only one of the Azure Pipelines jobs so we still get the benefit of testing it via CI but still reduce the quantity of requests by 75-80%. I think the --remote-data flag would be best executed in 'Test_bare_linux' since it would be the easiest to troubleshoot from but I could be convinced otherwise.

items.title: Equation for pvlib.irradiance.aoi_projection
items.body:
Hi,
I am trying to use pvlib.irradiance.aoi_projection function to to compute beam radiation on a plan. The objective is to fill gaps in experimental campaign with data from CAMS service.

I got the amount of radiation (W/m²) using the aoi_projection  function and multiplying by CAMS Beam normal radiation.  But throughout the year, the results were not consistent with the measurement. 

Looking at the equation, I had questions :
assuming :
- Surface tilt angle : 0° to <=180° and 0° is plan facing upward
- Solar zenith : angle in degree from the ground
- Surface azimuth : angle in degree between 0° and 360°. 0° being north, 90° being east, etc.
- Solar azimuth : angle in degree between 0° and 360°. 0° being north, 90° being east, etc.

The actual equation is
_projection = (
        tools.cosd(surface_tilt) * tools.cosd(solar_zenith) +
        tools.sind(surface_tilt) * tools.sind(solar_zenith) *
        tools.cosd(solar_azimuth - surface_azimuth))_

I understand the azimuth projection, but not the zenith

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18069111/73944559-184a5980-48f3-11ea-84d2-5265509e42cb.png)

Shouldn't the first part of the equation be ?
_tools.sind(surface_tilt) * tools.cosd(solar_zenith) - tools.cosd(surface_tilt) * tools.sind(solar_zenith)_

Thank you !

items.title: test_forecast failures with pandas 1.0.0
items.body:
Pandas has released v1.0.0.  With pandas 1.0.0, `test_forecast.test_datetime` fails, as #872 shows in the test log.  It is not clear if the test itself is the problem: [these lines](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/fb1ab533ab9a4b87a3161d577215ef3d8f12ed74/pvlib/tests/test_forecast.py#L117) do not set a timezone.

```
    start = datetime.now()
    end = start + timedelta(days=1)
```

**Should `start` and `end` be timezone-aware?**  The intent of the test is not clear to me.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Install pandas 1.0.0
```
import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from pvlib.forecast import NAM

_latitude = 32.2
_longitude = -110.9
_tz = 'US/Arizona'
_start = pd.Timestamp.now(tz=_tz)
_end = _start + pd.Timedelta(days=1)

amodel = NAM()
start = datetime.now()
end = start + timedelta(days=1)
try:
    amodel.get_processed_data(_latitude, _longitude, start, end)
    print("Success with {}".format(pd.__version__))
except:
    print("Failed with {}".format(pd.__version__))
```

Now run with pandas < 1.0.0 (e.g., 0.22.0)

items.title: obtain a dedicated API key for testing NREL psm3
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
came up in #866 see this [comment](../pull/866#issuecomment-578345464) but related to most PR and testing in general - due to  [NREL PSM3 throttle limits for the DEMO key](https://developer.nrel.gov/docs/rate-limits/) the CI's frequently fail

**Describe the solution you'd like**
obtain a dedicated API key from [NREL developer network](https://developer.nrel.gov/) and upload it to [Azure pipelines as a secret variable](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/variables?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml%2Cbatch#secret-variables), ditto for Travis, then for testing, get this from `os.environ[<PVLIB TEST NREL API KEY>]` and use it instead of the DEMO key which has severe [throttle limits](https://developer.nrel.gov/docs/rate-limits/) and is shared by everyone

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
just live with the test failures, or skip theses tests from the CI's

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

items.title: v0.7.2 release planning
items.body:
I'm opening this issue to centralize the discussion of what will be in the v0.7.2 release. Please try to centralize your thoughts and discussion about the next release here or by numerical reference from another issue/PR E.g. #XYZ. 

This is a new strategy proposed by @wholmgren and @cwhanse for someone assigned this role as "release manager" to track how current issues, PRs and bugfixes will add up to a release and ultimately perform that release. They've nominated me for this role for an undetermined amount of time so I'll do my utmost to stake this path through a continued dialoge with the community. 

I plan to continue to utilize the [v0.7.2 milestone](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/milestone/29) as a means of communicating what is planned to go into the next release. This issue will be a forum for the the community to voice support for certain enhancements to be prioritized for the release that will then inform the milestones. Of course this could be disrupted by important bug fixes that need a quick release like for v0.7.1 but bumping the milestone version to the next release shouldn't add to the disruption.  Overall I'll be reviewing the status of current issues and PRs for how they fit into a future release. 
 
_To start the conversation, please let me know what you think about what's currently listed on the v0.7.2 milestone and let me know if there's a reason to add more or remove something. Also, please suggest methods for making this process easier, faster or clearer._

Thanks for your support!

items.title: Add a plotting wrapper that make it easy to get high-quality plots
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
pvlib is great and thanks to all the great contributions that exist. I don't necessarily see this as a problem, but rather an enhancement to have a plotting wrapper library based on plotly/ bokeh that makes it easy to prepare high quality plots instead of using matlplotlib. I am happy to take a first pass. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Ideal solution would include good wrappers for generally used plotting functions like scatter plot, bar chart, line chart etc. with options to customize to allow the user to customize as needed, but also cut down up-front work in preparing the figure. 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
This is just an enhancement, so I have not considered any alternatives, open to suggestions/ feedback.

items.title: Add ability to read local NSRDB PSM3 CSVs
items.body:
Unless I've missed something in the docs, the only pvlib function that parses PSM3 CSVs is `iotools.get_psm3`, which requires making a network request to the NSRDB PSM3 API.  It would be nice to be able to read local PSM3 files (e.g. those downloaded manually from the [NSRDB Viewer](https://maps.nrel.gov/nsrdb-viewer/)) in addition to requesting them from the web API.  Here are a couple proposals:

- Break out the parsing code in `iotools.get_psm3` into its own function `iotools.read_psm3`, leaving `get_psm3` as a networking wrapper around the PSM3 API that then calls `read_psm3` on the API response.  
- Modify `get_psm3` to check if the input is a filename instead of API parameters and retrieve data as appropriate. 

I'd favor the former since it separates networking code from parsing code.  Some other `iotools.read_*` functions can make web requests, but those are just simple urls and more or less equivalent to reading a local file whereas `get_psm3` has to construct a full API request.

items.title: adopt NEP-29
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
the travis-ci test fails for #823 because the minimum NumPy version for py35-min is version 1.10.4 - the `np.roll()` function used was updated to allow multiple axes in NumPy-1.12

**Describe the solution you'd like**
[NEP-29](https://numpy.org/neps/nep-0029-deprecation_policy.html) is a proposal by maintainers of IPython, Matplotlib, SciPy, and NumPy that proposes the support window for Python and Numpy.

TL;DR: in the immediate future, drop support for Python-3.5 and Numpy<1.14

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
- statically create the 3 rotation matrices, removing the use of `np.roll` completely
- use the pre-NumPy-1.12 version of `np.roll`

**Additional context**
Since many other major packages that are used by pvlib are conforming to NEP-29, it makes a lot of sense for pvlib to also conform.

items.title: PV LIB - ECMWF - functionality is not compatible with non-global ERA5 files
items.body:
***Description/Details***
When working with ERA5 netCDF files which are not 'global' (i.e. lat -90 to +90 and lon -180 to +180) the `pvlib` function `get_nearest_indices` returns incorrect values due to an incorrect derivation of the grid size intervals. The appropriate grid size inside `get_nearest_indices` the derived ERA5 grid spacing does not correlate with the actual 0.25 degree grid spacing which is represented in all ERA5 netCDF files (geo-subset or otherwise). Ultimately this results in data being returned for the wrong lat and lon position based on a misaligned file index. This is something which could be resolved by ensuring the standard 0.25 degree value is used for the `delta_lat` and `delta_lon` values when instantiating a ECMWF object from a geo-subset netCDF file. Thank you.

*** Perhaps this should be a feature request instead but logging as a bug due to the incorrect values being returned 'silently'.

**To Reproduce**
*Assume you have a geo-subset (CONUS) ERA5 netCDF file path stored in the variable filePath
```
  met = pvlib.iotools.read_ecmwf_macc(filename  = filePath,
                                      latitude  = 34,
                                      longitude = -101.25)
```

**Expected behavior**
The ECMWF object has a lat, lon delta defined as 1.8 versus the correct 0.25 which results with incorrect row indices being used in the met data return and therefore not representing the requested lat and lon position which is input.

items.title: Pre-release announcement: pvlib-python v0.7
items.body:
We're close to release of pvlib-python v0.7. This will be a **major** release including (but not limited to):

- refactor temperature models to a new module `temperature.py` (API changes)
- refactor incidence angle modifier models to a new module `iam.py` (API changes)
- update module and inverter parameter files (new files have a different format)
- add a new module `ivtools.py` with functions for fitting diode models to data
- removal of some deprecated functions.

A full list of changes to date is [here](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/master/docs/sphinx/source/whatsnew/v0.7.0.rst).  

We plan to merge several open PRs for v0.7: #807, #805, #808, #804.  We may clean up some of the open issues that are currently marked for v0.7.

If you have an open pull request that still needs work, or are considering a pull request in the near future, please respond so that we can plan accordingly.

items.title: Add Wavelet Variability Model (WVM) for calculating spatial smoothing of irradiance
items.body:
> > Should I spin this off to a separate issue, since it might be different (and more compartmented) than the broader downscaling discussion?
> 
> Yes. Let's start a new module with this submission, `scaling.py` comes to mind, but I'm not enamored of it. Scope will be functions that operate on irradiance, perhaps other variables, to transform temporal or spatial characteristics.

Spinoff from [issue #788 ](https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/issues/788). Implementation is a python port of WVM, released as an auxiliary to the Matlab pvlib [here](https://pvpmc.sandia.gov/applications/wavelet-variability-model/). My implementation ports the original model logic, but deviates from the overall package, in that I begin at the point where the user already has a clear sky index to operate on (original starts from GHI and calculates POA clear sky index). I thought this would allow for more flexibility in choice of transposition model, etc, but it does ask a bit more work up front for a user to run the WVM.

I am close to completion of a draft and will create a pull request when ready. This is my first contribution to the project (or any open source project really), so please accept my apologies in advance if it takes some guidance.

items.title: fix tools._scalar_out to account for Series.item deprecation
items.body:
`tools._scalar_out` calls `input.item()` to reduce an array or Series to a scalar. But the `Series.item` method is deprecated as of pandas 0.25, so we need to do something different. Maybe first call `np.asarray` so we know we have a numpy array and then we can call `.item()`.

Also should replace the reserved argument name `input` with something else.

items.title: rethink module-level model parameters dictionaries
items.body:
#783 is adding a `iam.IAM_MODEL_PARAMS` dict that's simply sets of required parameters for IAM models. 

#682 added `temperature.TEMPERATURE_MODEL_PARAMETERS` that includes default values.

#548 added `pvsystem.DC_MODEL_PARAMS` that's also only sets of required parameters.

We should reconsider if we want to expose these dictionaries to users.

These dictionaries are used by methods in `PVSystem` and `ModelChain` to automagically determine what functions to call. In principle, user code might do something similar with them, but I doubt that happens.

The `TEMPERATURE_MODEL_PARAMETERS` dictionary with default values is probably the most useful to an end user because the default parameters are useful when calling `temperature` module functions directly (i.e. not through ModelChain/PVSystem).

My short term recommendation is to:

* deprecate `pvsystem.DC_MODEL_PARAMS` into `pvsystem._DC_MODEL_PARAMS`. I'd also be ok with just changing it without deprecation because 1. 0.7 is a big release and 2. this change won't effect many people and 3. My time is limited.
* change `iam.IAM_MODEL_PARAMS` to `iam._IAM_MODEL_PARAMS` to prevent problems before they start
* leave `TEMPERATURE_MODEL_PARAMETERS` alone

items.title: Isotropic Sky Diffuse geometry
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The traditional conversion factor ((1 + cos(tilt)/2) used in the isotropic sky model to calculate sky diffuse irradiance is geometrically inaccurate. The implementation of this model is in pvlib.irradiance.isotropic()

The original model that Hottel and Woertz developed is only a 2-dimensional consideration. The geometry argument is best put forward in https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2011.06.042

There are two suggested improvements. One is the linear expression put forward by Tian et al. The other is the diffuse tilt factor (DTF) developed in the above paper. Both are more geometrically sound than the original model by Hottel and Woertz.

items.title: Rounding issue in clearsky.py _linearly_scale method
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
In the _linearly_scale method, there are two logic statements (lines 316 and 321) that first round values to one decimal place, then compare if <= .5. Since they're being rounded first, values like .54 would become .5, then the check <= .5 would actually be true. Also, from a performance standpoint, there is no reason to round first, we could instead just do the comparison immediately. If you actually want to check if values are < .55, then write that explicitly and modify the comment on line 314. Or keep <= .5 and the leave the comment as is, but either way, there's no need to round and compare to a float. I can make a pull request for either approach, please just let me know what's preferred.

**To Reproduce**
```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> arr = np.array([.49, .50, .54, .55, .56])
>>> np.around(arr, 1) <= .5  # current behavior
array([ True,  True,  True, False, False])
>>> arr <= .5  # intended behavior and also much faster
array([ True,  True, False, False, False])
>>> arr < .55  # equivalent to current behavior but much faster
array([ True,  True,  True, False, False])

```
**Expected behavior**
I would have expected values like .54 to raise an error in this if block, but they don't.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: 0.6.3
 - python: 3.5.2

**Additional context**
Removing the unnecessary rounding operation reduces the runtime of these logic checks by about 60%.

items.title: `forecast.get_data` doesn't allow extra kwargs
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

`forecast.get_processed_data` accepts `**kwargs` (good) and passes these to `get_data` (good) and `process_data` (good):
https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/91c6a559feab740a346099f020fedf828ad9a557/pvlib/forecast.py#L306-L306
but `get_data` doesn't allow superfluous keyword arguments (bad):
https://github.com/pvlib/pvlib-python/blob/91c6a559feab740a346099f020fedf828ad9a557/pvlib/forecast.py#L202-L204

Is the fix just to add `**kwargs` as the last argument to `get_data`? If so, you can assign this issue to me and I'll make a PR.

**To Reproduce**

```python
import datetime
import pandas
from pvlib import forecast

forecast.NDFD().get_processed_data(
    38.238875, -117.363598, 
    pandas.Timestamp(datetime.datetime.now(), tz='US/Central'),
    pandas.Timestamp(datetime.datetime.now(), tz='US/Central') + pandas.Timedelta(hours = 12),
    how = 'liujordan'
)
```
Yields
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/anaconda3/envs/tonopah/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pvlib/forecast.py", line 306, in get_processed_data
    return self.process_data(self.get_data(*args, **kwargs), **kwargs)
TypeError: get_data() got an unexpected keyword argument 'how'
```

**Expected behavior**

I expect that `get_processed_data` is equivalent to:
```python
model = forecast.NDFD()
data = model.get_data(
    38.238875, -117.363598, 
    pandas.Timestamp(datetime.datetime.now(), tz='US/Central'),
    pandas.Timestamp(datetime.datetime.now(), tz='US/Central') + pandas.Timedelta(hours = 12)
)
model.process_data(data, how = 'liujordan', extra_kwarg=False)
```
Note how I can pass `extra_kwarg` without any problem.

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: 0.6.3
 - ``pandas.__version__``:  0.24.2
 - python: 3.7.3

items.title: NREL MIDC parser variable mapping makes too many assumptions.
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The iotools MIDC Parser produces duplicate column names in the returned DataFrame.

NREL MIDC data's labels are not formatted with enough consistency for pvlib to automatically map to native variable names. For example, some MIDC stations use brackets to differentiate similarly named columns, while others use paranthesis. The [UNLV](https://midcdmz.nrel.gov/apps/daily.pl?site=UNLV&live=1) site returns a csv with `Global UVE [W/m^2]` and `Global UVE [index]` as labels for variables 'Global UVE' and 'Global UVE (index)' respectively. iotools parses both of these names info `ghi_UVE`.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Running the following code will return a dataframe with duplicate `ghi_UVE` labels.
```
import pvlib
import pandas as pd
df = pvlib.iotools.read_midc_raw_data_from_nrel('UNLV', pd.Timestamp('20190501'), pd.Timestamp('20190502'))
df.columns
```
Returns:
```
Index(['Unnamed: 0', 'Year', 'DOY', 'PST', 'dni_Normal', 'ghi_Horiz',
       'ghi_UVA', 'ghi_UVE', 'ghi_UVE', 'Dry Bulb Temp [deg C]',
       'Avg Wind Speed @ 30ft [m/s]', 'Avg Wind Direction @ 30ft [deg from N]',
       'Peak Wind Speed @ 30ft [m/s]', 'UVSAET Temp [deg C]',
       'Logger Temp [deg C]', 'Logger Battery [VDC]',
       'Wind Chill Temp [deg C]', 'dhi_Horiz_(calc)', 'solar_zenith',
       'solar_azimuth', 'airmass'],
      dtype='object')
```

**Expected behavior**
Instead of applying a generic mapping automatically, a user should be able to pass in an optional `VARIABLE_MAP ` dictionary to use for renaming columns to . The default behavior should be to return the MIDC data as a DataFrame with their original labels.

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: 0.6.1
 - ``pandas.__version__``: 0.24.2 
 - python: 3.7.2

items.title: Erroneous timestamp parsing in UO SRML reader
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The parser for UO SRML data does not parse times correctly for 5 minute, 15 minute and hourly data. This is caused by the logic for handling the time format in SRML files always assuming one minute data.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
import pvlib

# requests a 15 minute file
pvlib.iotools.read_srml_month_from_solardat('TW', 2019, 5, 'RQ')
```
Returns:
```
                          ghi_1  ghi_1_flag  dhi_1  dhi_1_flag  temp_air_1  temp_air_1_flag        ...   
2019-05-01 00:14:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11         1.0               11        ...               
2019-05-01 00:29:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11         0.3               11        ... 
2019-05-01 00:44:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11        -0.9               11        ... 
```

**Expected behavior**
Timestamps should be parsed to align with each hour and to label the beginning of each time interval as noted in the function documentation. e.g. The result of the example above should be:
```
                          ghi_1  ghi_1_flag  dhi_1  dhi_1_flag  temp_air_1  temp_air_1_flag        ...   
2019-05-01 00:00:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11         1.0               11        ...               
2019-05-01 00:15:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11         0.3               11        ... 
2019-05-01 00:30:00-08:00    0.0          11    0.0          11        -0.9               11        ... 
```

**Versions:**
 - ``pvlib.__version__``: 0.6.1
 - ``pandas.__version__``:  0.24.2
 - python: 3.7

items.title: Remove times kwarg from ModelChain.prepare_inputs and ModelChain.run_model
Remove clear sky fallback option from ModelChain.prepare_inputs and run_model
items.body:
`ModelChain.prepare_inputs` and `ModelChain.run_model` currently default to running a model using clear sky data if none of `ghi`, `dni`, and `dhi` are in the input `weather`.

My original motivation for including this feature was that it would make it easier to get started with ModelChain. But it's not practically useful and arguably makes the documentation of an already confusing class even worse. 

It also violates the "explicit is better than implicit" guidance -- better to require that users provide their own data. Their own data is only a method call away with `location.get_clearsky`.

items.title: PVWatts_loss was applied on AC calculation
items.body:
Hi, 
    In the description of pvwatts_losses function, the losses are applied on DC side:
'Calculates DC power losses according the PVwatts model using pvwatts_losses() and self.losses_parameters.`' 
    However I found that in pvlib.modelchain.ModelChain.pvwatts_losses, PVwatts loss was applied to AC. 
'def pvwatts_losses(self):
        self.losses = (100 - self.system.pvwatts_losses()) / 100.
        self.ac *= self.losses
        return self'
   When system have high DC/AC ratio, AC power output clips at a lower level as a result of these losses applied on the AC side.
